incidents.name: Origin, API, and CDN — Increased Latency and Error Rates

incident_updates.body: Between 10:27 UTC and 10:31 UTC our Origin and API experienced increased latencies and elevated error rates. Our Build system experienced build failures. Content may have failed to load from different edge CDN locations and TLS connection establishments may have suffer failures.

incidents.name: Agent Runners Outage

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.

From 6pm UTC October 20 until 7am UTC October 21, Agent Runners Service has been experiencing failures. We have determined the source of the issue, put a fix in place, and will continue to monitor its effectiveness.

incidents.name: Service Outage Issues

incident_updates.body: The issues impacting our services have been fully resolved. All systems are now operating normally. We appreciate your patience during this incident.
We're seeing each of the impacted Netlify services returning to a stable condition, and we're continuing to monitor for any further issues.

Our teams are closely monitoring the issue and collaborating with AWS to restore normal service as quickly as possible. Impact continues across several services, including Functions, Email, CDN (Intermittent connectivity issues and timeouts in some regions), ImageCDN, Agent Runners, and some Builds

We have identified and resolved the primary issue affecting our services. The problem was related to upstream infrastructure issues that impacted how traffic was being routed to our systems. We have made configuration changes to route around  the affected infrastructure
Impact continues across several services, including Functions, Email, CDN ( Intermittent connectivity issues and timeouts) , ImageCDN, Agent Runners, and delays in processing some Builds

We continue to experience CDN-related issues in the IAD (US-East-1)  regions. This may cause slow load times or intermittent errors for users served from these locations.
Our team is working with upstream providers to mitigate the impact and restore full performance. We’ll share another update as soon as we see meaningful recovery.
The upstream provider didn’t fully recover from the outage, and despite our services stay operational, our team continues to monitor the situation to ensure stability.

Starting 11:50 UTC the upstream provider is showing consistent recovery and not throttling our function creation anymore. Netlify Build error rates have been reduced to normal values. Our team is continuing to monitor the situation to ensure stability.

We are continuing to investigate increased Netlify Build error rates that contain functions that are deployed to us-east-1 region. For more urgent resolution, we suggest moving functions to a different region, see https://docs.netlify.com/build/functions/optional-configuration/?data-tab=TypeScript#region.
We are continuing to mitigate these service issues.

We’re seeing recovery across several services after an AWS outage affected our systems. AWS has posted details here: https://health.aws.amazon.com/health/status. Services are improving, and we’ll keep you updated as we confirm full restoration.

As of 6:56 am UTC, we have been experiencing issues related to an outage at AWS in US-East-1. Affected services include UI actions, outgoing emails from Netlify, builds, functions, as well as 500 errors during site loading.

incidents.name: Planned brownout – legacy Equinix CDN (action required)

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.

Sites still pointing to the legacy edge network (Equinix) with the IP 147.75.40.150 will be offline until the DNS is updated to the current IP address. Please follow this guide: https://www.netlify.com/changelog/equinix-ip-address-expiring-for-4-year-old-sites/. DNS propagation can take up to 24–48 hours, depending on TTL.

incidents.name: Intermittent DNS Connectivity Issues in LATAM

incident_updates.body:
Some users experienced regional DNS resolution issues due to a third-party network provider outside our control. Throughout the incident, our servers remained fully operational and continued serving web traffic without interruption.
We have not received any new reports and believe the issue has been resolved. Based on this and the external nature of the root cause, we are now closing this incident.

If you continue to experience DNS-related problems, we recommend updating your DNS settings to use a public DNS service such as:
8.8.8.8
8.8.4.4

Thank you for your understanding
We are currently monitoring the situation.

After further investigation, we have identified that the issue appears to stem from a regional network provider. Our servers are operating normally and continuing to serve web traffic without interruption.

This issue is related to DNS resolution and is outside of our direct control. We have escalated the matter with our upstream providers and are monitoring the situation closely.

As a workaround, we recommend updating client DNS settings to use a public DNS service such as:
- 8.8.8.8
- 8.8.4.4

This may help mitigate the issue for affected users.
We will continue to monitor the situation and provide updates as information becomes available.
We've seen recent reports of DNS errors for users in Latin America. We are currently investigating this issue.

incidents.name: Netlify Docs Site Inaccessibility

incident_updates.body:
Between approximately 4:15am UTC to 9:04am UTC, July 22, 2025, users experienced issues accessing docs.netlify.com. During this time, the site was unavailable due to an internal configuration issue affecting site delivery.

Our team quickly identified the root cause and implemented a fix. The site has been fully restored and is functioning as expected.

We apologize for any inconvenience this may have caused and appreciate your patience.
